fields.description:
Currently the maven process described in http://wiki.apache.org/lucene-java/PublishMavenArtifacts does not work (on mac)

It worked fine for the 4.0-alpha and 4.0-beta releases.

NOTE: This appears to be working on linux so I am going with that. But this seems strange it doesnt work on mac.
 
{noformat}

fields.summary: maven deployment scripts dont work (except from the machine you made the RC from)

comments.body:
I edited the comment after Uwe pointed out to me this was an authorization error.

Description shows the error on my mac: this has something to do with parent POMs.

I dont know why it works on my linux box.

The problem is that the POMs must be installed in the local repository (~/.m2) for this to work, otherwise it cannot resolve them. If you run the script on the *same* machine where you built the artifacts, this will work. This is confusing...
I think the deployment script should first install the artifacts again on the current machine's ~/.m2 before starting the upload.

Can we not use ~.m2 but a clean fresh directory?

I think its really scary for such scripts to rely upon the local state of my machine: This is too much magic.

top-level: "ant remove-maven-artifacts"
I think the release building scripts and also the deployment scripts should do this first.

Same for the settings.xml with cleartext password (this caused my initial 401 problem, no way in hell im leaving such a thing around on my computer).

Maybe ant could read the password like it does for GPG and handle this for us?

this deploy task allows you to specify a local repository. i think we should somehow 'install' the artifacts from the RC
into a fresh directory, and then deploy from that?

then there is no possibility of problems I think, unless I am missing something.

bq. this deploy task allows you to specify a local repository. i think we should somehow 'install' the artifacts from the RC into a fresh directory, and then deploy from that?

The artifacts from the RC are already a local repository, so it should (theoretically :) ) be possible to just point the deploy tasks at it?

That would be really nice. I couldnt tell if they were or not looking inside my .m2, but if we can just point this localRepository
at the same stuff passed in the -D then it wouldnt depend on your local machine at all...
the auth stuff could be nested here too maybe as properties rather then needing a settings.xml. we could read that in like GPG

bq. the auth stuff could be nested here too maybe as properties rather then needing a settings.xml. we could read that in like GPG

Looks like a {{remoteRepository}} declaration can have nested auth: [http://maven.apache.org/ant-tasks/reference.html#remoteRepository].

Note that this strategy would write plaintext credentials into the temporary ant file used to deploy.

bq. Note that this strategy would write plaintext credentials into the temporary ant file used to deploy.

Scratch that, the temporary ant file could read in the credentials.

Work in progress:

Credentials are prompted for by default; {{-Dm2.credentials.prompt=false}} will use {{settings.xml}} instead.  I was able to stage a fake 4.1.0-TEST distribution with no {{settings.xml}}.

The patch attempts to point {{<artifact:deploy>}} at the distribution directory via {{<localRepository>}}, but this seems to be ignored - it doesn't look there for POMs it needs.  The process stops when it can't find the {{lucene-parent}} POM.

I think the next thing to try is to explicitly point to all parent POMs via {{<artifact:pom>}}.

Thanks for working on this! I intended to take a stab at this and got distracted, sorry.

But this looks great, fantastic to remove the settings.xml step! 
Thats the first thing I tripped on, for some reason i didn't before with the alpha/betas...

So if you nest the artifact:pom with the exact location, the deploy target doesnt use localRepository?
Or does maybe it need both?

Seems to work! I nuked .m2 completely before running.
It succeeded and I checked repository.apache.org. Thank you!!!!!

A few minor nits below:

Correct, there was no echoing of password on linux! Though, I'm still concerned here.
Does this also happen on windows if you sign artifacts with your GPG key?
For the 3.6 releases I added the following to sign-artifacts-macro:

{noformat}
<echo>WARNING: IF USING JAVA5 YOUR PASSPHRASE WILL BE ECHOED BACK!!!!!</echo>
<input message="Enter GPG keystore password: >" addproperty="gpg.passphrase">
{noformat}

We should do the same here if this is also the case on windows (IF USING WINDOWS...)
and also add this warning back to our current codebase for gpg signing too! This is really not
a problem except when you dont expect it and people are looking over your shoulder,
then it can be a HUGE hassle.

one minor thing i ran into was that line 1381 redirects output so if it fails you dont know why... this happens e.g. if the
directory is typoed or something.

{noformat}
-Dmaven.dist.dir=~/rc2/lucene

Buildfile: /home/rmuir/workspace/lucene-trunk/lucene/build.xml

clean:

stage-maven-artifacts:

BUILD FAILED
/home/rmuir/workspace/lucene-trunk/lucene/common-build.xml:1381: exec returned: 2

Total time: 0 seconds
{noformat}

I know its redirecting output, just didnt know if there was some simple way instead of
failOnError=true if we could instead fail on a property with the captured output?
updated patch with my suggested improvements.

bq. Does this also happen on windows if you sign artifacts with your GPG key?

Yes.

bq. We should do the same here if this is also the case on windows (IF USING WINDOWS...) and also add this warning back to our current codebase for gpg signing too!

+1

bq. updated patch with my suggested improvements.

+1

bq. Does this also happen on windows if you sign artifacts with your GPG key?

Definitely not! The password is hidden! This is clearly a cygwin issue (and only if you use the cygwin console window). With the official Windows 7 cmd.exe in the official Windows console window the password is not shown. I never use cygwin for builfding on windows, why do you Steven? To run ANT and build artifacts a plain cmd.exe is fine.

Ah, also: if you run bash.exe in the official Windows console windows (not cygwin's own), it also works. It's a bug of the dumb cygwin-internal console window only (why do they have it?) - sorry, I have to rant about Cygwin; I use it, too, but only to execute find/sed/grep...
